reviewDescription: #Drop🍿🍿1/2 (Out of 5)Not At All Original, Very Predictable And No Reality To Be Found - A Fun “Fantasy”Directed by Christopher Landon this film is trying to be something where basic logic, reason and real world technology are nowhere to be found. It has a lot of action, stunt work and seemingly advanced technology written into it but the director and writers Jillian Jacobs and Chris Roach did not give real thought to the reasoning and quick oversimplification of how closed-circuit camera’s work, how they can be taken over and/or manipulated over cell phones. I don’t think even the CIA equipment is this sophisticated.The story is that of Violet (Meghann Fahy), a widowed mother who goes to an upscale restaurant to meet Henry (Brandon Sklenar), a charming and handsome date. However, her pleasant evening soon turns into a living nightmare when she receives phone messages/texts from a mysterious, hooded figure who threatens to kill her young son and sister unless she kills Henry. The baddie (played by Reed Diamond) and her sister (Violett Beane) both play key roles in the unfolding drama, with weird twists and lots of action.The film has a very sharp, deep and color pallet thanks to the cinematography by Marc Spicer and the editing by Ben Baudhuin with all the action and the stunts is really done well. The music is by Bear McCreary who, as I am familiar with his work, he does another great job helping the mood and tension up and downs of the film.It’s a fun little ‘science fiction’ film (written sarcastically) that looks good and is smooth with its sleek style, just forget reality all together and you’ll enjoy the action, special effects and stunts. P.S. Can someone tell me why its called “Drop”?Lorenzo M
reviewTitle: Not At All Original, Very Predictable And No Reality To Be Found - A Fun “Fantasy”
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2025

reviewDescription: Opinions are subjective so don’t judge until you watch yourself, but I personally thought it was a decent film. It really has you questioning on what will happen next and wanting to tune in to the very end. The acting was ok and the plot was decent. Nothing out of the ordinary, but a film that I know most would enjoy (if you’re into suspense). Give it a shot if you’re looking for something to watch

reviewDescription: CorelDraw has been a go-to graphics tool for many years in my toolbox.  Though creating or editing graphics is not a daily task for me, this tool provides so much flex and ability in design  If you'd like, there is a web-based trial that works very well.  Pricing for Graphics Suite 2025 comes in either an annual subscription or a one-time purchase so you can decide which is your best value.  I am an old-timer and have always preferred the full version over the subscription.If you have a need to create top-level graphics, this one is for you.
reviewTitle: CorelDraw is still a leader in graphics!
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2025
variant: Platform For Display: PC/Mac Download, Edition: Graphics Suite

reviewDescription: I own CorelDraw Graphics Suite X7 (boxed version) and have played around with CorelDraw Graphics Suite 2025.The changes are primarily evolutionary and not revolutionary from my perspective. The UI looks mainly the same but with some added niceties (i.e. there is Dark mode in the newer versions). I am still not happy about the object manager docker as it's always felt clunky and difficult to manage layers and objects. Definitely some improvements with the tools themselves but again they are mainly evolutionary. I am not interested in the "connected" features.CorelDraw X7 is officially certified to work in Windows 10 so I saw no reason to upgrade that. I also have the latest updates from the Corel website for it.Unfortunately, my main issues here are with the licensing system. As mentioned I own a boxed copy of CorelDraw X7. Some time ago Corel completely killed the activation servers for it (and many other old versions of Corel software). You can install and plug in the key (and the key shows up in your Corel account as authenticated), but the software itself won't activate. Corel had deferred the activation process to a 3rd party system called "ntitles" which has since ceased to exist. You really cannot use the old versions anymore due to activation servers being down.I contacted the Corel customer support and the main response was basically "we don't support installations of older versions of CorelDraw, and here is a small discount for the latest version". I don't want to be forced to drop half a grand to upgrade because the activation servers are down. I would want to activate if there are new features I need/want. So instead of releasing a small update to use the Corel activation server instead of "ntitles" they instead just try to get you to buy the latest version.So even if you were to buy CorelDraw 2025 it's unknown how long it will work before it becomes unusable due to missing activation support. I just cannot recommend such business model. To me that makes the software unreliable for long term use and I can't trust that my original .cdr files will be usable going forward.I have finally decided to leave CorelDraw and migrate to Affinity suite. Looks much more modern, is cheaper, has perpetual licensing, and there are versions of Affinity older than CorelDraw X7 that are still working just fine.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2025
variant: Platform For Display: PC/Mac Download, Edition: Graphics Suite

reviewDescription: This game is one of the best I ever played--for sheer simplicity and fun. The single-player missions include some tutorials that introduce the game's content, notably how to defeat the various enemies, use your weapons, and satisfy your objectives so you can exit.You play as Jake, a human, or Garathe Den, an 8-foot horned beast with serious muscle. Besides your fists, there are grenades and ninja stars; both are devastating weapons because you can throw 2-3 per second, enough to win most battles.Jake gets a weak pistol. It's not powerful, but certain enemies like mine generators and chamelons (moneky-ish things that can turn near-invisible) are pistol fodder. He has a shotgun that proves itself useful in most battles, and his most powerful weapon, the rocket launcher. Believe me, once you have that tube and 99 rockets, nothing's going to stand in your way for long.Garathe has knives; they fly in a straight line and do some damage, and if they get stuck in a wall you can run and pull 'em out. He gets a mash-them-up! club that sends enemies flying and some serious damage. He even gets a whip that throws plasma bolts; they knock most anything to the ground.There's multi-player levels, and you can choose to play as Garathe or Jake, along with (shirt for Jake, fur color for Garathe) red, brown, black, and white colors--heck, you can be the same character for grins. In these MP levels, you and a friend get to fight it out in one of 20 levels and compete for the most kills; most of these levels are designed just for two humans to fight it out, but there are a few with significant enemies or hazards if you want a challenge.The co-op levels (15 altogether) are a lot of fun except for the one called "The Blue One." You don't choose your character, but it's a SP mission on steroids and like in the SP missions, you have to complete an objective or two, then find the exit to complete the level.The gameplay is very straightforward, like any arcade game, and even slow learners should have a good grasp of it after only a few hours of playing. The game doesn't hog system resources either, so its graphics (1990s era) look great, and the sound effects like Garathe's grunting as he climbs ladders are realistic-sounding.I don't recommend listening to the heavy metal and techno soundtracks on the CD, because they might be disturbing to some young listeners, but the game doesn't require its CD to run, so you can insert your own music and run it from the in-game drop-down menu.This came out before internet gameplay, so there's no way to play this online, but with the sheer number of levels for SP, MP, and co-op, you won't be begging for it anytime soon.Overall, this game is one of the most original, fun, and dark I ever played. I highly recommend it.

reviewDescription: I have had inexpensive language learning program before but this one is awful.  You have to memorize a bunch of words-and they don't explain when to use "il" "e" or "gli" for "the" (in fact, they don't even tell you that is Italian for "the"  I just happen to know it).  I am not a big grammer person but I think it's important so you can figure it out in real conversation.  After you "pass" the first CD of memorization then you go onto the next totally different learning style CD (like it's a different language program).  Some of the memorization from this CD doesn't follow the memorization from the 1st CD (doesn't use "the" in front of the word has different names for the same word etc.).  The 3rd CD is even worse...it gives you phrases (some of them totally useless) that you have to memorize and try to spit back.  Again, no grammer cues as to how to put a sentance together.  Maybe a toddler learns this way (over a 2-5 year period) but as an adult learner I was hoping to learn a little better for my trip to Rome.  I am not going to use the phrase "can you heat up this jar of babyfood"!  There is no cohesion between the CDs and there is no real learning.  I gave up after seeing the 5th CD and I couldn't understand a darn thing...it went from memorization to "immersion"-no spoken English...and they sure in the heck weren't speaking the phrases I had memorized!
reviewTitle: only if you have a good memory
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2009

reviewDescription: If you're looking for something that will present words to you in English and then have you repeat them in Italian, then this might be for you, but I haven't found that to be an effective way to learn how to speak a foreign language.  I don't see how it would be any better than an audio book.It requires that the CD be present in the computer when it runs, which is a complete nuisance (I understand they do this for copy protection purposes, but a) it's easy to copy CDs if that's your goal, and b) it's not worth copying).  One of the reasons I bought this product was so I could install it in my work, home, and notebook computers (something Rosetta Stone doesn't allow), but since it executes from CD ROM, it's not going to useful on my optical drive-less notebook, and it's going to run slower on the desktops than a program run from the hard disk.But even setting aside the annoyance factors, I just don't like the way it allegedly teaches.  It presents several groups of words, and says the goal is to get 1800 points.  I'm not sure how I'm supposed to get 1800 points, and I'm not going to waste any time trying to find out.

reviewDescription: As someone who has used rosetta stone products and now this instant immersion, I have noticed some interesting information. Instant Immersion claims to be similiar to rosetta stone but "about 500 dollars" cheaper. The product is certainly similiar, in lesson one, pictures are displayed, the name (in the foreign language) is heard on the speakers, and the english word for the item is displayed next to the picture. This happens several times. Then, the user hears the audio for one of the pictures and must choose. With rosetta stone, the user sees the picture, hears the audio, and sees the spelling all in the foreign language. Please note that I am comparing one part of each program that I found to be the most useful in actually learning the language. The claimed price difference is accurate as well; three levels of rosetta stone can be bundled currently for roughly $480.
reviewTitle: Similiar to rosetta stone, not identical
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2011

reviewDescription: I love this and have learned a lot from it!! Its easy to learn and love the way they have the two different people saying the same word or phrase... makes it easier when you hear multiple ways to say it! Have fun with it!!
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2011

reviewDescription: I have used Rosetta Stone and this product.  I agree that neither are quite what they promise, which is an EASY way to learn a language.  For someone to compare this favorably to RS is highly suspicious to me.  After multiple failed attempts to get this product to work on my Mac, I went to a PC laptop to actually check it out.  This product compares to Rosetta Stone in the way that a fast food hamburger compares to a well-prepared steak.  This is really nothing more than a mildly-interactive vocabulary list.  Perhaps that's worth the money, but don't confuse it with the advanced learning procedures from Rosetta Stone.  My problem with RS is that they do not show you enough direct translation vocabulary.  So in that sense, this would be a nice complement to RS.  The audio CD's included in this are actual lessons, thus not really helpful for drilling and memorizing.  It's really not comparable to RS at all, and any comparison is incredibly unfair.  They should take those claims off of their packaging.  I'll be demanding a refund for the Mac incompatibility, but otherwise would make use of the money back guarantee.  Save yourself the hassle.
reviewTitle: Mac problems and not comparable to RS

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2008

reviewDescription: Some of the games look like they will be good for my elderly mother, although she has not tried them yet. There are so many that the disk will be worth it even if she likes just a few of them. She can play these without the constant ads and scamming of games online, which is a big plus, and they are different from the online games that she has tired of. The graphics are low-resolution and the general feel is dated, but that is no problem for a 90-year-old! Other reviewers report that the disk must be in the optical disk drive for the game to work. I did not verify that. To avoid that inconvenience, I used public-domain software (WinCDEmu) to make an .iso file version of the disk and to mount the .iso file; I then ejected the physical disk and installed the  from that mounted "virtual optical disk". The games work fine without the physical disk in the optical drive (on a Windows 7 PC), including after rebooting. In reading the disk to make the .iso file, the software found many bad sectors on the disk, which might be part of the copy-protection scheme that requires the disk in the drive. But installing from the resulting .iso file worked anyway, and the few games and features that I have tested so far have all worked as intended. I don't know for sure that this more complicated approach is needed, but it did work, so my mother can just click an icon on her desktop to start the games without having to insert the physical disk.
reviewTitle: Good for an older parent; how to use without disk in drive
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2018

reviewDescription: I had all kinds of difficulty installing this game. i finally had to have someone else do it for me. But once it was on, I have played it over and over. There is a ton to choose from. Lots of different games and lots of characters to play with. This just has everything from basic checkers to mahjong games with 50 different tile layouts to choose. It has battleship that can be set to play however you wish.. one shot each per turn to 5 shots each per turn. it has a game similar to alchemy and another similar to tetris. it also has a sorry type game that's played with race cars. A bunch of solitare card games, chess, a yatzee-ish game and lots more. Each one has lots of options for play (easy to hard) and there are probably twenty different characters who are aminated and talk. Makes for a fun package with lots to do and people to play with. Once I had it loaded I love this package. It even has several versions of dominos, maze races and a tic tac toe game. And there are many games I haven't even mentioned.  You could spend a lot of money buying all those separately. hard to beat. I would for sure buy it again and have already shared it with friends.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in Canada on December 16, 2010

reviewDescription: Hoyle Card Games has been a staple in our house since the very first version way back in the day (when it came on 5.25" disks).  Over the years, I think we have had every single version.  Some of the versions have taken a little getting used to, so I was prepared for an adjustment period.The 2009 version is dreadful.  It's awful, a travesty.  I am shocked and dismayed to even find the good name of Hoyle attached to such a lackluster and disappointing product.I know it's petty and silly, but I miss the little lizard. He's been gone for a couple of versions and I was hoping he would be back.  I miss the weiner-dog too.  With all the technology and the space available on a DVD, you would think they could maybe add in some of the old characters or maybe some new ones.  These appear to be the exact same ones that have been available in 2008 (and 2007).The whole 'purchase scenery and card pieces' idea...eh.  It's ok.  I don't like or dislike it, necessarily.  I don't see the point or know why they bothered.The cards are STILL too small. [Note, there was some kind of patch from last November that apparently increased the size of the cards, they are STILL too small]The "Card Speed" in the Environment settings is a joke.  It appears to be a slider bar (much like an X-axis on a graph) with major and minor tick marks.  But you can't adjust to a minor tick mark.  The second to the fastest major tick mark is sloooooow (and my computer is running Vista on a 2.8 GHz processor with 8 GB of RAM) and the all the way fastest tick mark is so fast you can't even see cards move...you just hear the flips in the background.  I'm even afraid to try any slower setting, I don't have years to watch the cards move.Cards are selected by a scrolly list at the bottom which doesn't work well and which the spouse says 'is sea-sickening.'Scores are no longer reported on the game field.  WHAT?  Yes, you read correctly.  While playing a game you can now only see your score between hands.You now only have two choices for sorting (ascending and descending).  Depending on the game I am playing this makes things difficult.  While playing Gin, I don't use simple ascending, I group by pairs, sets or runs...but I can't do that in Hoyle 2009.  I don't have the option of a custom sort or even unsorted.They tried to be fancy and create "rooms" you can play cards in.  There is scenery, background and a table you all sit around.  The problem is that most of the games have a 45 degree angle on the table, which makes the entire playing surface difficult to see, fuzzy and tiny.  I was perfectly happy with the older versions where the cards just kind of sat on the borders of the screen.  It worked very well and was functional.  Why fix what isn't broken?The interface has been changed and very much not for the better.  All right click functionality is gone.  In some games (like Canasta) you have to left-click a card and drag it to the appropriate spot on the table, which is fuzzy, difficult to see and (in many cases) BLOCKED by the card you are dragging.Some of the AIs seem to be more intelligent.  The bridge AI does seem to have some improvement over previous versions and the spades AI doesn't seem to trump my aces like the older versions.However, even with a slight improvement in AI, the interface is so awful that the game is nearly unplayable.  If I could return the game, I would.  Instead, I'm probably going to reinstall the old version (2008, iirc) and see if maybe I can't sell 2009 on eBay.Oh, I thought I might write Encore an email and tell them about the problems I had with the game...but there doesn't appear to be any way to contact them directly (from the info on their website) except by snailmail.  That seems rather odd to me (and rather fishy) for a company that is making computer games.  I can't help but think it's done on purpose.They seem to have some link with Broderbund (from PrintShop fame).  Considering their lack of technical support, a [purposeful] inability to contact the company and an extremely poor quality of product, I believe that unless something amazing happens in the near future I will not purchase any other product from Encore (or Broderbund).Hoyle Card Games 2009 is that bad.  It's so bad I'm going to avoid the manufacturer and their other products.  Take it to heart and RUN, do not walk away from this game...buy 2007 or 2008 instead.  You will be MUCH happier.
reviewTitle: RUN, don't walk away from Hoyle Card Games 2009
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2009

reviewDescription: This product is OK but I don't like it as well as the earlier edition (2005) we have on another computer.  Problem is the old one will not operate on Windows 7.  For instance, in the Gin game on the old one you can reposition the cards in your hand for runs or pairs or trips; in the new one you cannot and it makes it more difficult to keep up with your hand.  Additionally, when a hand is won in the old one both hands are shown so you can compare and then see the scoring.  In the new one it just goes to the scoring and you never see what was in your opponents hand.  In Solitaire the movement of the cards seems somewhat disjointed and the reset button is positioned in an uncomfortable position.  I must say though that the graphics are drastically improved in the 2009 version

reviewDescription: This is a dystopian film where civilization is similar to the 12th century in style and function, down to the Crusader Knight outfits.  Gray Alys (Milla Jovovich) is a witch being hanged in the first scene. Using her mind control and illusion ability, she manages to escape. She is being hunted. She also grants wishes, but they are similar to those of the Mokey's Paw. With every wish comes a price. The Queen (Amara Okereke), who is cheating on the near-dead King, asks Alys for a wish. She requests to become a shape-shifter, to be able to transform into a wolf.  Alys must travel into the Lost Lands ( a burnt-out city) to find a werewolf and kill it. She hires Boyce (Dave Bautista) as a guide.There is a lot of action as Milla revives her fighting skills from previous films. The witch aspect adds another dimension to a film short on colorful characters.Guide: No swearing, sex, or nudity.

reviewDescription: #InTheLostLands0 (Out of 5)Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson from a screenplay by Constantin Werner from story by Anderson and Constantin Werner (Based on "In the Lost Lands" by George R. R. Martin) about a witch that travels to the Lost Lands in search of a magical power that allows a person to transform into a werewolf….yawn.Everything about this movie is predictable. The dialogue is hysterical. It plays like a very bad Tele-Novella complete with static and stoic lines, cliché’s of close-up and forced relationships. It was so bad it was not only boring, but funny to watch. And not in the good way.Starring Dave Bautista and Milla Jovovich (both a VERY big yawn) the film has no meat, no real original purpose. I think it is trying to be a weirdly produced, but bad copy of a “Mad Max” -like movie – without an original story, characters or point to the society created in this world. The film is gritty and completely looks CG’d throughout by cinematographer Glen MacPherson and faded cuts and wipes from editor Niven Howie don’t help the dull pace. A very artificial looking and feeling film. Even the music by Paul Haslinger was weirdly intense out of context to what the visuals were.Hard, super-duper pass on this one…Lorenzo M
reviewTitle: OMG. Why? Just Why? Completely CG Sets, Environments And A Tele Novella Story

reviewDescription: Many games have tried to make variations of other games to compete with either, other companies, or other games. Either way, competition is always the demand for any company trying to survive in this world.This game is a variation of "Oregon Trail" game, only this is based on a bicycle race and you have to do your best to stay alive in the African country. The idea is you are given a set of items and a limited amount of funds and you have to use those limitations to try and, not only survive the race, but also make it through the rough areas of Africa itself. Your strength, stamina, and how well you manage your resources are all going to be considered and tested, throughout the game. This game is deal for people who want to learn about the ways to survive in a bike race through Africa and is great for all ages.Something you should know is that, this game was designed to run under Windows 3.1/95/98/XP. This game will not run on Windows Vista/7/8 as the game is too old for todays technology. Also, because the game is so old, tech support is no longer in service and is no longer considered due to the age of the game itself. So, the only way this game will work is if you still have a working copy of Windows 3.1-XP, otherwise you are just wasting your money. For collectors of old games and people who still have older machines.
reviewTitle: A good game, based on the "Oregon Trail" game, but only works for older Windows PC's...

reviewDescription: I have spent months on the road in Africa, though in bush taxis and not on a bicycle. I have also lived as a Peace Corps Volunteer and have traveled through areas similar to some of those traveled on this trip. I love how this software has captured the textures and flavors of so much of Africa. I only wish that computer software could communicate smells and tastes. One little thing that I wasn't expecting at all was how well the bargaining compares to the real thing--and how it changes from one part of Africa to another.One thing that is important: when I first ran the software in Windows XP, it was real little and disappointing. Make sure you set the software to run at 640x480 resolution (in the shortcut properties in Windows XP). That will make the program run full-screen and you will see it as intended.
